prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Parties have sought remand as part of the relief on appeal from decisions of the transferee court. In one case illustrating this issue, the Eighth Circuit firmly rejected this kind of attempt, noting that the appellant could seek remand from the Panel.[1] The relief was sought from the appellate court on the grounds that the transferee court had previously decided factual issues in resolving a summary judgment motion, thereby making it somehow inappropriate for that judge to continue to sit in the case.

There is no proper basis for any appellate court to order remand of any action on appeal. The power to order remand is granted by statute to the Panel, and the decisions of the Panel are subject to the limited review allowed by extraordinary writ.[2] Appellate courts that have jurisdiction over appeals from the decisions of a transferee judge do not have any jurisdiction over the issue of remand. There is no reason, however, why the appellate court could not suggest remand to the Panel. The Panel takes into account the views of the transferee court when considering the remand issue.[3] The Eighth Circuit in Pfizer advised the parties of their option of seeking remand from the Panel but did not comment on the appropriateness of remand.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
In re Coordinated Pretrial Proceedings in Antibiotic Antitrust Actions, 538 F.2d 180 (8th Cir. 1976), cert. denied, 429 U.S. 1040, 97 S. Ct. 738, 50 L. Ed. 2d 751 (1977).
28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(e). The statute is reprinted in § 3:19. Review by writ is discussed in chapter 11.
The role of the formal suggestion of remand by the transferee court in the remand decision by the Panel is discussed in § 10:6.
